items.title: Incorrect Read Command Output INFO Message for Multiple Connections
items.body:
I observed this behaviour during SSH to Windows machine.
Let's say there are 2 SSH connection to Windows. (say ssh1 and ssh2).
A command is executed using Start Command keyword on respective sessions (say cmd1 & cmd2).
While reading the output, an incorrect INFO(cmd2 instead of cmd1) message is displayed, which may further prompts us for incorrect debugging. Please find the screenshot below.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11714466/85003717-37e07100-b174-11ea-9176-346a1802ebac.png)

Code snippet below:
```
    Switch Connection    ${i}
    Start Command    timeout 5
    Switch Connection    ${j}
    Start Command    hostname
    Switch Connection    ${i}
    ${out}    ${err}=    Read Command Output    return_stderr=True
    Switch Connection    ${j}
    ${out}    ${err}=    Read Command Output    return_stderr=True
```

items.title: Open Connection from current connection

Hello,

I am looking to open a nested ssh session from my current ssh session. I've noticed that the Open Connection keyword always open a new connection from the root host. 
Is there a way to open the connection from the host on which I have already a connection opened ?

Thank you

items.title: Stopping command started by "Start Command"
items.body:
Currently non-blocking commands are started via the 'Start Command' keyword. 
However there does not appear to be a way to stop the command once started.

Brief example:
```
Open Connection   my_host
Start Command  "netcat -l 8282"
Close Connection
```

Netcat will still be running in background. I have attempted writing a Ctrl+C down while connection is still open. Correct me if I am wrong, but it does not appear to reach the background shell.

items.title: Read Until: very slow feedback
items.body:
Hello,
I'm currently using the SSHLibrary to launch a console application, monitor the console output, and wait for a particular line to appear to stop the running application.
It should return PASS if the line has been read, or FAIL if timeout occured.
The problem I'm facing is that it is very slow to get the feedback of Read Until compared to the actual time when the test has produced to expected line on the console.
For example, I have a test which produce the expected line in about 5 seconds. But when doing the same test in robotframework, the Read Until will block for almost 2 minutes before returning with the line read.
The amount of data printed on the console is about 15000 lines.

The script looks like this:
test_5
    Open Connection     ${ip_address}
    Login               pi    raspberry
    Set client Configuration	timeout=10 minutes
    Write               ./test_app
    Read Until          Received 1 packets (total:785)
    Execute Command	kill -SIGKILL ${pid}

Any idea why it is so long to process compared to real-time ?

Thanks and regards,
Michael

items.title: Login with password fails even with correct credentials (confirmed by sshclient)

labels.name: acknowledge
labels.description: To be acknowledged in release notes

items.body:
With some server implementation that requires a null authentication before a password, SSHLibrary Login/Connect fails with even correct credentials.

For example, those servers has this kind of behavior
```
debug1: match: OpenSSH_3.9 NetBSD_Secure_Shell-20050213 pat OpenSSH_3.* compat 0x01000000
```

A pull request is recommended to solve this problem  https://github.com/robotframework/SSHLibrary/pull/327

items.title: [SFTP] `create remote file` fails when server denies chmod command

labels.name: acknowledge
labels.description: To be acknowledged in release notes

items.body:
We are running a SFTP server where access rights are controlled by the server.

When we use SSHLibrary to upload a file to, the underlying SFTP client tries to execute a `chmod` command that is denied by the server.

Robot Framework only receives `OSError` as message.

We are going to propose a fix for this particular issue, where it is possible to upload a file without setting the mode.

items.title: It's possible to switch to already closed connection

labels.name: acknowledge
labels.description: To be acknowledged in release notes

items.body:
It seems an old problem came back in SSHLibrary 3.3.0:

https://github.com/robotframework/SSHLibrary/issues/120
https://github.com/robotframework/SSHLibrary/issues/233

When connection is closed using `Close Connection` it's still possible to switch to this connection. Any subsequent call results in `AttributeError`:

```python
>>> from SSHLibrary import SSHLibrary
>>> ssh = SSHLibrary()
>>> idx = ssh.open_connection('10.143.3.50')
>>> ssh.close_connection()
>>> ssh.switch_connection(idx)
>>> ssh.read()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "[...]/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/SSHLibrary/library.py", line 1301, in read
    return self._read_and_log(loglevel, self.current.read, delay)
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'read'

>>> ssh.close_connection()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "[...]/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/SSHLibrary/library.py", line 669, in close_connection
    connections.close_current()
  File "[...]/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/SSHLibrary/sshconnectioncache.py", line 18, in close_current
    connection.close()
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'close'

```

items.title: Get Directory behavior differs based on whether the destination exists
items.body:
The end result of using Get Directory differs when the destination does not exist compared to when it does. If the source is the following: 
dir_to_get
    └── subdir_to_get
          └── file_to_get
then using ``Get Directory /tmp/dir_to_get /tmp/destdir recursive=True``, results in the following: **A) /tmp/destdir exists** 
tmp
    └── destdir
        └── dir_to_get
            └── subdir_to_get
                └── file_to_get
**B) /tmp/destdir did not exist** 
tmp
    └── destdir
        └── subdir_to_get
            └── file_to_get
It would seem logical that the end result should be that of A) in both cases as this seems to be the intention with the fix to #270.

items.title: Execute Command: Channel Exception;(4,Resource Shortage")
items.body:
In https://github.com/robotframework/robotframework/issues/2704 the channel Channel Exception;(4,Resource Shortage") was initially reported.

I am unable to replicate using paramiko directly (and exactly as the original reporter did), however I am seeing the same issue when running from inside robot framework when using `execute command` but write + read until transactions function properly.  This has been observed on all cisco IOSXE devices.

```
#!/usr/bin/env python2
import paramiko

try: 
  ssh = paramiko.SSHClient()
  ssh.set_missing_host_key_policy(paramiko.AutoAddPolicy())
  ssh.connect('xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx',username='user',password='password',look_for_keys=False, timeout=60)
  stdin, stdout, stderr = ssh.exec_command("show version")
  print stdout.read()

except:
  stderr.read()

finally:
  ssh.close()
```

items.title: Removing connections from connection list breaks switch_connection when followed by a close_connection

labels.name: acknowledge
labels.description: To be acknowledged in release notes

items.body:
we noticed some weird problems in our upstream automated testing in OpenDaylight, and it started
happening with the release of SSHLibrary 3.2.0

here's a snippet to reproduce it:

`from SSHLibrary import *

ssh = SSHLibrary()
cids = []
cid = ssh.open_connection("127.0.0.1")
cids.append(cid)
cid = ssh.open_connection("127.0.0.1")
cids.append(cid)
cid = ssh.open_connection("127.0.0.1")
cids.append(cid)
cid = ssh.open_connection("127.0.0.1")
for c in cids:
    print("working on: " + str(c))
    old_cid = ssh.switch_connection(c)
    print("old_cid: " + str(old_cid))
    ssh.close_connection()`

essentially, we get to a list of cids of [1,2,3] and internal _connections of [0,1,2,3]
on every switch_connection, we end up switching to [index - 1], but now that we
are really removing the connection from _connections, that list reduces on a
close_connection so [index - 1] is wrong.

items.title: Login With Public Key authenticates successfully using invalid keyfile

labels.name: task
labels.description: Generic task not listed in release notes

items.body:
Currently login_with_public_key  will still pass even if you provide an invalid keyfile as long as you provide the correct user password in the 'password' parameter. According to documentation, 'password' parameter should act as a 'passphrase' for the keyfile if it is needed. Current implementation seems to default to normal log in when invalid keyfile is provided. 
I think 'password' should no longer be provided using this keyword since users really intend to login using their provided keyfile and should fail if this is invalid. 'password' argument should also be replaced by 'passphrase' to avoid confusion for provided 'passphrase' for the keyfile.

items.title: Get/Put File keywords do not return folders containing square brackets
items.body:
https://github.com/robotframework/SSHLibrary/blob/42785d9a9a1649c6006a0550ce150a30f4b78af6/src/SSHLibrary/abstractclient.py#L997
Folders that contain square brackets in their name (ie. 2018-08-16_10-31-48_TEST-[1]test_name) are not properly returned by this list comprehension. Glob.glob is the culprit here since [ ] are considered special characters and need to be escaped.
This is important because test tracking software like IBM Quality Center uses naming conventions that require every test to start with [1] and automatic test reporting to QC is in this case much easier if TC name is aligned with QC name.

items.title: Permission Denied for Put File with correct permissions
items.body:
I was getting a permission denied when trying to call Put File on a file that already existed.  If this file hadn't existed already, the call would succeed but if the file DID exist, I'd get this error.  I've narrowed it down to the chmod that occurs in the put file, more specifically in the _create_remote_file method in pythonclient.py.

    def _create_remote_file(self, destination, mode):
       destination = destination.encode(self._encoding)
       remote_file = self._client.file(destination, 'wb')
       remote_file.set_pipelined(True)
       self._client.chmod(destination, mode)
       return remote_file

I recreated this issueby having a testuser that was in the vagrant group on my VM.  

    [vagrant@ansible issue]$ groups testuser
    testuser : testuser vagrant

In a directory owned by vagrant:vagrant, I created a directory and in it a file.

    [vagrant@ansible issue]$ ls -al
    total 4
    drwxrws---. 2 vagrant vagrant   21 Jun 18 18:12 .
    drwx------. 4 vagrant vagrant 4096 Jun 18 18:07 ..
    -rw-rw-r--. 1 vagrant vagrant    0 Jun 18 18:12 file.txt

Because testuser is in the vagrant group and perms are set up the way they are, I'd expect we can copy up files/replace files.  And we can normally.  

    [testuser@ansible issue]$ touch otherfile.txt
    [testuser@ansible issue]$ ls -al
    total 4
    drwxrws---. 2 vagrant  vagrant   41 Jun 18 18:39 .
    drwx------. 4 vagrant  vagrant 4096 Jun 18 18:07 ..
    -rw-rw-r--. 1 vagrant  vagrant    0 Jun 18 18:12 file.txt
    -rw-rw-r--. 1 testuser vagrant    0 Jun 18 18:39 otherfile.txt
    [testuser@ansible issue]$ cp otherfile.txt file.txt
    [testuser@ansible issue]$ ls -al
    total 4
    drwxrws---. 2 vagrant  vagrant   41 Jun 18 18:39 .
    drwx------. 4 vagrant  vagrant 4096 Jun 18 18:07 ..
    -rw-rw-r--. 1 vagrant  vagrant    0 Jun 18 18:39 file.txt
    -rw-rw-r--. 1 testuser vagrant    0 Jun 18 18:39 otherfile.txt

The only thing I can't do is chmod file.txt in there. 

    [testuser@ansible issue]$ chmod 660 otherfile.txt
    [testuser@ansible issue]$ chmod 660 file.txt
    chmod: changing permissions of ‘file.txt’: Operation not permitted
    [testuser@ansible issue]$ ls -al
    total 4
    drwxrws---. 2 vagrant  vagrant   41 Jun 18 18:39 .
    drwx------. 4 vagrant  vagrant 4096 Jun 18 18:07 ..
    -rw-rw-r--. 1 vagrant  vagrant    0 Jun 18 18:39 file.txt
    -rw-rw----. 1 testuser vagrant    0 Jun 18 18:39 otherfile.txt

Because of this, I propose that in the SSH library that if a file already exists and we didn't specify a mode for the directories/files, we don't attempt to chmod.

items.body:
This is at least very similar, if not exactly the same as the already closed #102.
After opening SSH connection (in this case using public key) and closing it with "Close Connection" keyword, the opened connection is still shown when "Get Connection" or "Get Connections" keyword is called, and "Switch Connection" can be used to switch to that connection, but "Execute Command" fails because of "Connection not open" error.

The SSHLibrary version used was 2.1.3 and Python version was 2.7.12, as seen also in the attached [RFW log pdf](https://github.com/robotframework/SSHLibrary/files/2027305/log.pdf)

A simple test case that can be used to reproduce the error is like this:

```
*** Settings ***
```

items.title: Command is terminated after 0.1 seconds when sudo_password is used
items.body:
When calling `SSHLibrary.execute_command(command='sleep 5', sudo=True,  sudo_password='mypassword')` (or `SSHLibrary.start_command(...)`), the function closes the SSH shell if the command took longer than 0.1 seconds.

This is happening because of [this](https://github.com/robotframework/SSHLibrary/blob/master/src/SSHLibrary/pythonclient.py#L236) code:

    def _execute_with_sudo(self, sudo_password=None):
        ...
        if sudo_password is not None:
            stdin = self._shell.makefile('wb', -1)
            stdin.write(sudo_password + '\n')
            stdin.flush()
            time.sleep(0.1)  # flags from _shell_open() not updated without this sleep
            # in case of incorrect password close the shell
            if self._shell_open():  # This line causes execution termination.
                self._shell.close()

As I understand, the code assumes that if the command is not finished in 0.1 seconds after we entered the password, then the password is incorrect. This logic works for short-living (<0.1 seconds) commands, but fails for long-living ones.

I am not familiar with SSH protocol, so I don't know the general solution to this problem.
Can we peek stdout and check for the string "Sorry, try again." in case of incorrect password? Or have that string as a `SSHLibrary.DEFAULT_SUDO_WRONG_PASSORD_MESSAGE`?


Here is an example *\*.robot*:

    *** Settings ***
    Library  SSHLibrary
    
    *** Variables ***
    ${target_address}  10.42.0.2
    ${username}  <username>
    ${password}  <password>
    
    
    *** Test Cases ***
    
    Execute sudo command
      SSHLibrary.Open Connection  ${target_address}  prompt=$
      SSHLibrary.Login  ${username}  ${password}
    
      ${stdout}  ${stderr}=  SSHLibrary.Execute Command  sleep 5; echo end   return_stderr=True  sudo=True  sudo_password=${password}
      SSHLibrary.Close Connection

and output *log.html*:

    10:38:13.634 	INFO 	Executing command 'sudo sleep 5; echo end'.
    10:38:13.634 	DEBUG 	[chan 1] Max packet in: 32768 bytes
    10:38:13.741 	DEBUG 	[chan 1] EOF sent (1)
    10:38:13.742 	INFO 	Command exited with return code -1.
    10:38:13.742 	INFO 	${stdout} = <password>
    [sudo] password for <username>:

    10:38:13.742 	INFO 	${stderr} =

items.title: Separate section for explaining the time syntax
items.body: Nowadays there are several keywords accepting timeouts that all explain the time syntax briefly. Would be better to add a new section into the library introduction explaining it once.

items.title: Inconsistent usage of Boolean arguments
items.body:
Currently some (most?) keywords use Robot's `is_truthy` with Boolean arguments and thus consider string `False` (case-insensitively) to be false. Others (at least `List Directory`) just look at the truth value of the argument, which means any non-empty string (including `False`) is considered true. The former approach is obviously better, and we should go through all the keyword and make sure they follow that.

In addition to making sure that all keywords handle Boolean arguments consistently, how they handle them should be documented. Good examples of such documentation can be found from [XML library](http://robotframework.org/robotframework/latest/libraries/XML.html#Boolean%20arguments) where it as also adapted to SeleniumLibrary as part of robotframework/SeleniumLibrary#719.

It would be nice to fix this in SSHLibrary 3.0.0, but I don't consider this severe enough to be a blocker if it's otherwise ready.

items.title: SSHLibrary.Put Directory: UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xb7 in position 18: invalid start byte
items.body:
From time to time we've problems using the SSHLibrary.Put Directory keyword. Last time putting a directory structure stops at a PNG file. At that time it was easy to solve by deleting the PNG image. But right now Copying the directory structure stops at a shared library - a binary file.

In both cases I get an encoding issue:

> UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xb7 in position 18: invalid start byte

This time a don't know a solution - I can't continue.

Also to mention: Pythons run in `venv` environment.

Here comes the trace of the operations:

```
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.628] thr=2   paramiko.transport.sftp: [chan 1] stat(b'/tmp/VNE/modules/pcan/libpcanbasic.so.4.2.0')
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.629] thr=2   paramiko.transport.sftp: [chan 1] stat(b'/')
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.631] thr=2   paramiko.transport.sftp: [chan 1] stat(b'/tmp')
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.632] thr=2   paramiko.transport.sftp: [chan 1] stat(b'/tmp/VDA')
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.633] thr=2   paramiko.transport.sftp: [chan 1] stat(b'/tmp/VDA/modules')
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.634] thr=2   paramiko.transport.sftp: [chan 1] stat(b'/tmp/VDA/modules/pcan')
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.636] thr=2   paramiko.transport.sftp: [chan 1] open(b'/tmp/VDA/modules/pcan/libpcanbasic.so.4.2.0', 'wb')
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.637] thr=2   paramiko.transport.sftp: [chan 1] open(b'/tmp/VDA/modules/pcan/libpcanbasic.so.4.2.0', 'wb') -> b'00000000'
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.637] thr=2   paramiko.transport.sftp: [chan 1] chmod(b'/tmp/VDA/modules/pcan/libpcanbasic.so.4.2.0', 484)
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.693] thr=3   paramiko.transport.sftp: [chan 1] close(b'00000000')
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.693] thr=3   paramiko.transport: Dropping user packet because connection is dead.
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.706] thr=3   paramiko.transport: [chan 0] EOF sent (0)
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.706] thr=3   paramiko.transport: Dropping user packet because connection is dead.
DEB [20180424-15:59:47.706] thr=3   paramiko.transport: Dropping user packet because connection is dead.
```

This looks like a encoding issue, but both sides (source and target) use
> LANG=en_US.UTF-8

### Steps to reproduce
Well, here I can't actually provide steps. Copying `libpcanbasic.so.4.2.0` worked for weeks, but as of today it stopped working.

### Current behavior
Copying the directory structure stopped at copying `libpcanbasic.so.4.2.0` with the error
> UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xb7 in position 18: invalid start byte

### Expected behavior
I expect that the `libpcanbasic.so.4.2.0` is copied as any other file. 


### Version
```
DEB [20180424-16:33:30.409] thr=1   paramiko.transport: Local version/idstring: SSH-2.0-paramiko_2.0.4
DEB [20180424-16:33:30.543] thr=1   paramiko.transport: Remote version/idstring: SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_7.2p2 Ubuntu-4ubuntu1
INF [20180424-16:33:30.543] thr=1   paramiko.transport: Connected (version 2.0, client OpenSSH_7.2p2)
```

items.title: Implement creation of SSH tunnels with Paramiko
items.body:
Hi RF team,
as first explained in the SSHLibrary slack channel it would be good to have a keyword that will create a `local SSH tunnel` natively within Paramiko. 

The use case for that feature is to enable RF to talk to the SSH hosts indirectly.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5679861/38771161-94bd99e6-4026-11e8-8b3f-bc162f30acc0.png)

Its very common to have a `bastion` host that is exposed and the SUTs that are sitting behind it. Without the local tunnels (aka `ssh local port forwarding`) its impossible to talk to these "remote" hosts

Paramiko has a [native method](http://docs.paramiko.org/en/2.4/api/transport.html#paramiko.transport.Transport.request_port_forward) to request such tunnels. Also this [implementation example](https://medium.com/@ismailakkila/black-hat-python-ssh-tunnelling-with-paramiko-7df71445cab) might help.

So something like `Create Local SSH Tunnel` would make a very good addition to this beatiful library. Currently we hacked the following:
```
Create Local SSH Tunnel
    [Arguments]
    ...    ${local_port}=9500
    ...    ${target_host}=${None}  # i.e. 10.20.30.40:22
    ...    ${tunnel_host}=${None}  # i.e. root@10.2.3.4
    ...    ${tunnel_host_ssh_port}=22  # i.e. root@10.2.3.4
    ...    ${priv_key}=~/.ssh/cats
    
    ${p_path} =  CATSUtils.Parse Path    ${priv_key}

    ${pid} =  Process.Start Process
              ...    ssh -p ${tunnel_host_ssh_port} -i ${p_path['full_path']} -L ${local_port}:${target_host} ${tunnel_host}
              ...    shell=yes
    
    CATSUtils.Wait For SSH to Be Ready
    ...    host=localhost
    ...    port=${local_port}

    [Return]    ${pid}
```
which works but has a drawback of demanding cert-based SSH access only. With the pure paramiko implementation it would be possible to also support a password based authentication which is often the only auth method possible

/cc @mihaiparvu

items.title: Command execution should take into account user configurable timeout
items.body:
I've encountered a case wherein executing SSH command would hang up in PythonSSHClient transport.open_session() even when timeout is set during SSHLibrary.SSHClient instantiation. 

Shouldn't the following code use the timeout passed to SSHLibrary.SSHClient(host=host, timeout=**timeout**)?
https://github.com/robotframework/SSHLibrary/blob/9c116dd960bceca5bfbcfc009780f3fe57509ac4/src/SSHLibrary/pythonclient.py#L86

Based on paramiko documentation, open_session() accepts timeout parameter.
http://docs.paramiko.org/en/2.4/api/transport.html#paramiko.transport.Transport.open_session

items.title: sudo for  "Execute Command" and "Start Command"
items.body:
Background: Pretty much all linux distributions and their users are now (and for a long time already) denying direct root logins via ssh. "sudo" must be now used to execute commands that require an elevated session . This makes using SSHLibrary a bit difficult because the nice&easy "Execute Command" and "Start Command" can not be used for such sudo-requiring setup. The users of SSHLibrary are forced to the interactive prompt and the "raw"-commands like "read" and "write": first to enter elevated session via sudo ... and then all the actual commands need to be executed using the cumbersome interactive prompt as well.

Would it be possible to enhance the "Execute Command" and "Start Command" to execute the command in an elevated sudo session? (Maybe by passing sudo parameters for those KWs, or "Login" or "Open Connection" ...or something else).

During test creation and to follow what happens in web browser, we run a `pyrobot` over SSH to some runners to get the X11 Forwarding, but it does not work.

items.title: Cannot open connections with Paramiko 2.1.0
items.body:
Paramiko added an optional parameter "timeout" to `transport.start_client()`:
https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/blob/2.1.0/paramiko/transport.py#L449

`client.connect()` now passes the `timeout` parameter:
https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko/blob/2.1.0/paramiko/client.py#L338

This results in a TypeError in SSHLibrary's _custom_start_client
`TypeError: _custom_start_client() got an unexpected keyword argument 'timeout'`
https://github.com/robotframework/SSHLibrary/blob/bfc1558c1651e345fa33d752f4ae38576725d6a1/src/SSHLibrary/pythonclient.py#L31

items.title: New paramiko version causes connection failures
items.body:
Paramiko versions 2.0.3 and 2.1.0 have been released today and since this SSHLibrary requires paramiko >= 1.8.0, the latest lib is fetched. The two newest paramiko versions seemed to have introduced an issue with a missing timeout argument. 

The workaround is to explicitly require paramiko 2.0.2 in your application's requirements.

items.title: SSH library dependencies no longer supported
items.body:
The SSHLibrary depends on paramiko, which (used to) depends on PyCrypto.  The latest version of paramiko, 2.0, now depends on Cryptography.  This breaks the SSHLibrary.  When attempting to Login, I'm getting the following error: 

ImportError: dynamic module does not define init function (init_constant_time).

Workaround: Uninstall paramiko 2.0 and cryptography and install paramiko 1.7.5 from source, https://pypi.python.org/pypi/paramiko/1.7.5 (bringing PyCrypto along with it).
